child.pub-comments: Nex Perce is a Sahaptian language. Two dialects are distinguished, Upriver and Downriver, correlated with the original settlement pattern along the snake River and its tributaries in eastern Washington and Idaho. The Upriver dialect is spoken fluently by a handful of elders at Kamiah and Lapwai on the Nez perce reservation in north-central Idaho, and by several more on the Colville reservation in eastern Washington. The Downriver dialect is mainly preserved by a few speakers on the Umatilla Resevration in Oregon (most of the descendants of Cayuse speakers who adopted Nez perce in the nineteenth century). In addition to these fully fluent speakers there are between 30 and 40 speakers and semi-speakers of varying degrees of fluency, most of them in Idaho.

child.pub-comments: Sahaptin is a Plateau language of marked dialectal diversity spoken along the Columbia River and adjacent Plateau in eastern Oregon and Washington. Together with Nez Perce it forms the Sahaptin branch of the plateau family. Southern Sahaptin (or River) varieties were originally spoken along the Columbia River from the Dalles to the Umatilla River, and included Tenino, Wayan, and Umtilla. Northwest Sahaptin varieties were spoken in the Yakima River drainage and included Klickitat, Taitnapam, Upper Nisquallay, Yakima and Kittitas. Northeastern Sahaptin varieties were spoken on the Columbia River above Southern Sahaptin and along the lower Snake river and included Walla Walla, Wanapam, and Palouse. The principal surviving Sahaptin communities are on the Warm Springs Reservation in nothern Oregon (about 50 speakers of Tenino); on the Umatilla Reservation in northeastern Oregon,

child.pub-comments: Klamath-Modoc is the Plateau language originally spoken, in shallowly differentiated dialects, by both the Klamaths of south-central Oregon and the Modocs of the Tule Lake area in adjacent northeastern California. After the Modoc war of 1872-1873 about 150 Modocs were relocated in Oklahoma, the remainder merging into the Klamath community. The Modoc dialect is extinct in Oklahoma. The Klamath dialect has continued to be spoken in and around the former reservation community of Chiloquin, Oregon. In 2001 only one very elderly first-language speaker survived.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Ives Goddard, Victor Golla, J. Lachlan Mackenzie, Marianne Mithun & Mauricio J. Mixco. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 8. London, New York: Routledge.

child.pub-comments: Molala was formerly spoken along the western slopes of the Cascades in central Oregon, from the Upper Rogue River to the vicinity of Mt. Hood. It is a Plateau language, distantly related to Klamath and Sahaptian; an earlier classification that linked Molala and Cayuse in the :waiilatpuan' family has been abandoned. The Molala were displaced and suffered a severe decline in population after the white occupation of their territory in the mid-nineteenth century. The survivors were settled on the Grand Ronde Reservation, where their language and tribal identity was lost. The last speaker died in 1958.
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle , Ives Goddard, Victor Golla, J. Lachlan Mackenzie, Marianne Mithun & Mauricio J. Mixco. 2007. Atlas of the World's Languages, 2 edn., 8. London, New York: Routledge.
